content.description:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Electrons from the oxidation of glucose and other nutrients by glycolysis and the Krebs cycle are added to the electron-carrying compound <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>NAD</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> to form <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. To meet the continuous requirement for <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> by cells, <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>NADH</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> is oxidized back to <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> through the electron transport chain, in the presence (<math alttext="which is represented by a plus sign" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) of oxygen, or through fermentation, in the absence (<math alttext="which is represented by a minus sign" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) of oxygen (Figure 1).

Figure 1. A simplified model of metabolism and the recycling of <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="M T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-<math alttext="N D 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mi>D</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is a mitochondrial gene that encodes a subunit of <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dehydrogenase, the enzyme that catalyzes the initial oxidation of its substrate <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> in the electron transport chain of mitochondria. A mutation in <math alttext="M T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-<math alttext="N D 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mi>D</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is associated with a rare genetic disorder that results in a buildup of lactic acid in the body. A researcher hypothesizes that the mutated <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dehydrogenase has decreased activity but is not completely nonfunctioning and that, by increasing the pool of <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in cells, the activity of <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dehydrogenase will increase.

To test this idea, the researcher treated a group of individuals with this disorder with a vitamin that is similar to <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and measured the concentration of <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and lactic acid in the blood over the course of 20 weeks. The results from a representative individual are shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2. The concentration of <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>NAD</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> (top) and lactic acid (bottom) in the blood of a representative treated individual
content.question: (a) Describe the pattern of inheritance that is most likely associated with a mutation in the <math alttext="M T" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>M</mi> <mi>T</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>-<math alttext="N D 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mi>D</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. Explain why individuals are not typically heterozygous with respect to mitochondrial genes.

frqParts.text: (a) Describe the pattern of inheritance that is most likely associated with a mutation in the <math alttext="M T" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>M</mi> <mi>T</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>-<math alttext="N D 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mi>D</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. Explain why individuals are not typically heterozygous with respect to mitochondrial genes.

(b) Identify a dependent variable measured in the researcher’s experiment. Identify one control that the researcher could use to improve the validity of the experiment. Justify the researcher analyzing blood samples at many intermediate time points instead of at only the beginning and the end of the 20-week period.

(c) Describe the relationship between the concentration of <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> in the blood and the concentration of lactic acid in the blood during the first 5 weeks of treatment with the vitamin. Based on Figure 2, calculate the average rate of change in blood <math alttext="N A D with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> concentrations from week 5 to week 17.

(d) The researcher performed a follow-up experiment to measure the rate of oxygen consumption by muscle and brain cells. Predict the effect of the <math alttext="M T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-<math alttext="N D 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mi>D</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> mutation on the rate of oxygen consumption in muscle and brain cells. Justify your prediction. The researcher had hypothesized that the addition of the vitamin that is similar in structure to <math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> would increase the activity of the mutated <math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> dehydrogenase enzyme in individuals with the disorder. Explain how the vitamin most likely increased the activity of the enzyme.
